thread.title: Africa Cup of Nations kit power rankings: Home and away shirts rated and slated
thread.title_full: Africa Cup of Nations kit power rankings: Home and away shirts rated and slated

author: Joe Mewis
title: Africa Cup of Nations kit power rankings: Home and away shirts rated and slated

organizations.name: getty images / getty images / getty images

text:
(Photo: Getty Images / Getty Images / Getty Images) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Now that we're closing in on the knockout stage of the Africa Cup of Nations , we can begin to answer one burning question. 
Not who will be lifting the trophy, who the surprise package is, nor the top goalscorer. 
But instead it's time to look at which side in Gabon is wearing the best kit. 
As is regulation in international tournaments, everyone is wearing them, and - for completely self-imposed reasons - we can chose only one to top our rankings. 
Sadly, there are no real curveballs in shape of Cameroon's previous sleeveless or onesie versions of old, but there are plenty of vibrant efforts to sink our teeth into. 
So without further ado, here we go in descending numerical order... 28. Tunisia - home 
Very Switzerland away in Pro Evo 4. And not in a good way. 27. Ivory Coast - away 
Not much to see here. Next. 26. Egypt - away 
Plain as plain can be. Quite possibly signed off on a sunny Friday afternoon when everyone at Adidas Towers wanted to get down the pub for Callum from marketing's leaving do. 25. Tunisia - away (Photo: AFP) 
This one isn't winning any awards either. Strong number font helps drag up this uninspiring effort. 24. Senegal - home (Photo: AFP) 
In the 2003 Britpop documentary Live Forever, Liam Gallagher was asked who his hero growing up was . "The Incredible Hulk", he replied. Why, asked the filmakers. "I just liked his green-ness," the Oasis frontman sneered back. 
Being green isn't enough to save this kit from being far too dull, despite the sneaky-good socks. 23. Gabon - home (Photo: AFP) 
I don't reckon it took the Adidas design department long to dream this one up either. Nothing offensive about this Sweden-Ukraine identikit number, but this doesn't exactly get the pulse racing. 22. Egypt - home 
Another functional design from Adidas here. They've not got in the spirit. 21. Morocco - away (Photo: AFP) 
A tad busy on the top half, with the red armbands and green strip clashing with the Adidas stripes. Not a classic. 20. Algeria - home 
Not sure the v-neck goes with the coloured rectangle. Too many angles. Nice shorts, mind. 19. Burkina Faso - away (Photo: AFP) 
Straight out of turn-of-the-millennium Serie A. Made a mockery out of those who said you couldn't get 12 Kappa logos on a single pair of shorts. 18. Algeria - away (Photo: AFP) 
Unfussy, with the diagonal red line saving it from being boringly unfussy. But still a middle-of-the-pack effort. 17. Morocco - home (Photo: AFP) 
The Atlas Lions (a moniker which will feature highly in our international nickname power rankings) have the benefit of a maroon and green colour scheme which works well and they've not upset to applecart too much here, correctly opting for a darker shade. 16. Zimbabwe - home (Photo: AFP) 
Another kit where the socks are the best bit. The sweat-patch effect on the torso doesn't help, but the red piping works. 15. Uganda - away (Photo: AFP) 
A very good use of retro striping from the Cranes. A bit rough around the edges, but its distinctiveness makes up for it. 14. Zimbabwe - away (Photo: AFP) 
Suffers from the same sweat-patch problem the home kit does, but the strong collar game pulls it up a few places. 13. Guinea-Bissau - away (Photo: AFP) 
What started life as a Portugal home kit imitation has been clawed at to give a green shredded effect, which is a new one on me. Kudos. 12. Togo - away (Photo: AFP) 
Simple, but in a good way. Macron have come a long way since the 2004-05 Leeds United home kit. Pleasing shade of red and the higher-than-usual badges work well. 11. DR Congo - away (Photo: AFP) 
Plenty to like here. The blue stripe and the shirt is pleasingly thin and the shorts are good, too. Bonus point for getting the flag on there, as it's a good 'un. 10. Cameroon - home (Photo: AFP) 
The 2002 sleeveless effort was the Kid A of international kits and while the Indomitable Lions have eschewed the innovative spirit of old, they're still left with a very easy on the eye kit. Nice detail on the collar. 9. Uganda - home (Photo: AFP) 
Hard to look at without being reminded of 1980s Belgium teams, but that's not a bad thing. We're not used to seeing Uganda strut their stuff in global tournaments, but with kits like this, they can come again. 8. Guinea-Bissau - home (Photo: AFP) 
The AFCON newbies have doubled down on their torn-to-sheds style home kit and it's paid off handsomly. 7. Togo - home (Photo: AFP) 
Another strong effort from the Sparrow Hawks. No one's tried too hard to impress here, and it's resulted in a clean, simple and distinctive kit. 6. Mali - away 
Not seen such a strong Eagle game since Randall Cunningham was turning heads in Philadelphia 25 years ago. 5. Mali - home (Photo: AFP) 
This is a team that are proud of their national symbol and aren't afraid to show it. Put French manufactures Airness on your one to watch list. 4. Senegal - away (Photo: AFP) 
Here we go, the tournament's big divisive number. You either love the multicoloured lion (of Teranga, presumably) that is roaring onto the Senegal shirt, or you hate it. 
We'll take all of that you've got, thank you very much. 3. Ghana - home (Photo: AFP) (Photo: AFP) 
Ghana have always had cool kits and this current vintage is of no exception. The black star takes pride of place and the triangular piping around the collar and sleeves is on point. 
And when the likes of Asamoah Gyan and pals turn around we get treated to a glorious name-number colour combo. Woof. 2. Ivory Coast - home (Photo: AFP) (Photo: AFP/Getty Images) 
Ivory Coast's orange and green stylings always work well and Puma have absolutely nailed this one. This number has a distinct retro feel, giving off a 1970s NASL vibe. 
The tusks below the names on the back is the icing on a very tasty cake. It's that attention to detail that puts the Elephants in the running for the title. 1. DR Congo - home (Photo: AFP) 
This just works. The three colours of DR Congo flag are all present and correct and put together expertly without clashing in a distinctive kit that is not like any other. With strong socks and shorts it's the complete package. poll loading Which is the best kit at AFCON? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
